  • Element
com.sun.faces.annotation

Annotation Type Property


  • @Retention(value=SOURCE)
@Target(value={FIELD,METHOD})
public @interface Property
    Annotation that identifies a field or method as belonging to a JSF component property. A property is a logical entity that consists of three source artifacts:
    • a public "getter" method for reading the property value
    • an optional public "setter" method for writing the property value
    • an optional private or protected instance variable for storing the property value
    Any of these source artifacts may be annotated, however, it is preferable to annotate the property instance variable, if present, otherwise, the "getter" method. The "setter" method should be annotated only if it is used to override a method in a super class, and the "getter" method is not overridden. The annotation for a given property should occur only once per component.

    A property may be annotated in a component class, a non-component class, or an interface. It is generally a good idea to define common properties once, in an abstract base class or interface. Inherited property metadata may be overridden, by providing an annotation on the overriding getter or setter method. Annotation element values from the super class will be inherited unless overridden by annotation element values in the child class.

    A property is uniquely identified by its name(). If no name is provided, one will be supplied. If an instance variable is annotated, the instance name is used as the default property name. If a method is annotated, and the method name follows Beans naming conventions, a name will be deduced. The following annotations are equivalent, all resulting in a property with the name myProperty: 

        @Property()
    private String myProperty;

    @Property()
    public String getMyProperty();

    @Property(name="myProperty")

    Property read and write method names need be supplied only if the method names do not follow standard Java Beans conventions. The following example uses standard naming conventions: 

        @Property()
    private String myProperty;

    public String getMyProperty() {
        return this.myProperty;
    }

    public void setMyProperty(String myProperty) {
        this.myProperty = myProperty;
    }
    Whereas this example does not: 
        @Property(
        readMethodName="getMyPropertyPrettyPlease",
        writeMethodName="setMyPropertyPrettyPlease")
    private String myProperty;

    public String getMyPropertyPrettyPlease() {
        return this.myProperty;
    }

    public void setMyPropertyPrettyPlease(String myProperty) {
        this.myProperty = myProperty;
    }

    A property may or may not correspond to a JSP tag attribute. By default, properties are associated with tag attributes of the same name. For example, the annotation 

        @Property(name="myProperty")
    is assumed to correspond to a tag attribute also called myProperty. All of the following annotations are equivalent: 
        @Property(name="myProperty")
    @Property(name="myProperty",isAttribute=true)
    @Property(name="myProperty",attribute=@Attribute(name="myProperty"))
    @Property(name="myProperty",isAttribute=true,attribute=@Attribute(name="myProperty"))
    See the Attribute annotation for more information about attribute metadata. If a property does not correspond to an attribute, this information must be stated explicitly: 
        @Property(name="myProperty",isAttribute=false)
    If a property corresponds to an attribute with a name different from the property name, an attribute name must be provided explicitly: 
        @Property(name="myProperty",attribute=@Attribute(name="my-property"))

    The javadoc-formatted comment found with the annotated property declaration (field, getter method, or setter method) is also considered part of this property's metadata. Typically, the first sentence of the comment will be used as the property's default short description.

    Some property elements may be used to generated localizable values. Such elements are themselves annotated with the Localizable annotation.

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      Attribute attribute
      Metadata about the JSP tag attribute corresponding to this property.
      java.lang.String category
      The name of a property category descriptor, asserting that this property belongs to the named design-time category.
      java.lang.String displayName
      The display name, typically used at design-time.
      java.lang.String editorClassName
      The fully qualified name of a property editor class, to be instantiated by the IDE for editing this property's values.
      boolean isAttribute
      Indicates whether this property corresponds to a JSP tag attribute.
      boolean isDefault
      Indicates whether this property is the default property for its component.
      boolean isHidden
      Indicates whether this property should be hidden at design-time.
      java.lang.String name
      This property's unique name.
      java.lang.String readMethodName
      The name of the "getter" method for this property.
      java.lang.String shortDescription
      An optional short description of this property, typically used as a tool tip at design-time.
      java.lang.String writeMethodName
      The name of the "setter" method for this property.

    • Element Detail

      • name

        public abstract java.lang.String name
        This property's unique name. The name must be unique within the scope of the property's class. If no value is provided, the following logic is used to supply a default name: if a field is annotated, use the field instance name; if a "getter" method is annotated, and the method name begins with "get", use the remainder of the name, with the fist character translated from upper to lower case; if a "setter" method is annotage, and the method name begins with "set", use the remainder of the name, with the fist character translated from upper to lower case. If none of these condiditions are met, an error will be reported.
        Default:
        ""

      • displayName

        public abstract java.lang.String displayName
        The display name, typically used at design-time. If no value is provided, the name() will be used.
        Default:
        ""

      • shortDescription

        public abstract java.lang.String shortDescription
        An optional short description of this property, typically used as a tool tip at design-time. If no value is provided, the first sentence of the javadoc-formatted comment for this property will be used.
        Default:
        ""

      • readMethodName

        public abstract java.lang.String readMethodName
        The name of the "getter" method for this property. A value need be specified only if the annotation is placed elsewhere than the "getter" method, and if the method name does not follow the standard convention.
        Default:
        ""

      • writeMethodName

        public abstract java.lang.String writeMethodName
        The name of the "setter" method for this property. A value need be specified only if the annotation is placed elsewhere than the "setter" method, and if the method name does not follow the standard convention.
        Default:
        ""

      • category

        public abstract java.lang.String category
        The name of a property category descriptor, asserting that this property belongs to the named design-time category. The value must refer to an annotated category descriptor of the given name, found in the current compilation unit. See PropertyCategory.
        Default:
        ""

      • isDefault

        public abstract boolean isDefault
        Indicates whether this property is the default property for its component. Only one property may be declared to be the default property for a component. If a component does not declare a default property and does not inherit a default property, and implements javax.faces.component.ValueHolder, the value property will be made the default.
        Default:
        false

      • isHidden

        public abstract boolean isHidden
        Indicates whether this property should be hidden at design-time.
        Default:
        false

      • editorClassName

        public abstract java.lang.String editorClassName
        The fully qualified name of a property editor class, to be instantiated by the IDE for editing this property's values. An IDE will provide a reasonable default editor based on the property type.
        Default:
        ""

      • isAttribute

        public abstract boolean isAttribute
        Indicates whether this property corresponds to a JSP tag attribute.
        Default:
        true

      • attribute

        public abstract Attribute attribute
        Metadata about the JSP tag attribute corresponding to this property. This element must not be specified if isAttribute() is set to false.
        Default:
        @com.sun.faces.annotation.Attribute
